thread.title: Upgrading Windows or Mac OS? What’s your hurry?
thread.title_full: Upgrading Windows or Mac OS? What’s your hurry? | Dallas Morning News

author: Rossman
title: Upgrading Windows or Mac OS? What’s your hurry?
text:
It’s upgrade season.
Windows 10 is out now, and Mac OS 10 El Capitan comes out Sept. 30.
Apple phone users also have upgrade options, as iOS 9 dropped this week.
I get a lot of people asking me whether it’s OK to upgrade their computers or should they wait?
I always answer — it depends on a few things.
With big updates to a device’s core operating system, there’s rarely a need to be an early adopter.
There are going to be a lot of bugs with any new operating system. Do you want to help find those bugs or do you want to wait a bit and have a more trouble-free experience?
Some people, like me, love to be early adopters.
At work, when a new version of the Mac OS comes out, I know there are going to be users here who want to upgrade. They’ll be coming to me to ask if they should upgrade or wait.
Computers used for work need special consideration. Here we install the newest OS on a few computers and do some testing with all the software we use to put out a paper and website each day.
We have to make sure our core programs will work as expected before we start upgrading work computers.
A lot of us want to work from home as well, or use our home computers to connect to the office network.
At home, if your computer is used only for fun, by all means upgrade if you feel like it. If you rely on your computer for your livelihood, you might want to slow down. Take stock of exactly what software you use to do your job. Is there special software involved? Check with that company to see if it has started supporting the new OS.
Check user groups or Internet discussion forums to see if people have had any trouble upgrading.
Think long and hard about what would happen if your computer stopped working altogether. Do you have a backup plan?
If this makes you uneasy, slow down, do some reading and see what others have experienced. There’s likely no need to hurry.
Speaking of a backup plan, the days and weeks leading up to an upgrade are a great time to go through your hard drive, cull what you don’t use, and make sure you have a current backup.
This advice goes for smartphone users as well — delete any apps you don’t use and then make a backup of your phone.
I do phone backups to the cloud and to my local computer before any upgrade.
You might want to connect your phone to your computer and make sure your photos are backed up. Phone backups happen a lot faster if your phone is not full of photos.
